div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: The Future of Spain
div.p: The approaching marriage of the King? of Spain has thrown an unusual degree of interest on the young ruler of that ancient kingdom Those who would forecast the future and predict the fate of King? Alfonso have do- gularly little material to work upon. "Bourbon child of a Hapsburg mother,” he is the repre- sentative of the two great lines which have ruled Spain through such extraordinary vicissi- tudes of fortune for nearly four centuries. Charles the Fifth was King of Aragon and Casille before the conquest of Mexico or Peru; the minority of Alfonso the Thirteenth saw the last shred of its American Empire torn from the grasp of Spain. But of his personal characteristics and his mental and physical endowments, the world knows little. Born in the purple, he has been denied that training which falls to the lot of the Heirs apparent of the Royal Houses of Europe. Foreign travel has been impossible for him, equaly so has been that free association with his future subjects of equal age and congenial tastes, which is the lot of a Prince of Wales, a Prince of Naples, ora Crown Prince of Germany. And in his case the affectionate care of his mother, placed herself in a position of duel responsi- bility, has been pushed to extremes. We do not know if the Spanish language has any equivalent for oar word "coddled,” and we would not use it for worlds if it is in any degree disrespectful. Let us rather describe his education as akin to "that fugative and oloistered virtue” of which Milton wrote, and let us hope that the young King may find advisers round the Throne who will help and guide him as wisely as Queen Victoria was gaided through the opening years of her ’glorious reign. Ever since the close of the Peninsular War Spain has been the shuttlecock of despotism and revolution alternately. Oat of the chaos has been evolved one of those parodies of Parliamentary and party Government which ware the craze of the Nineteenth Century. It has not brought much prosperity to Spain, and the war of 1898 was the finishing touch to a long series of disasters. It must be added that that country has been singularly unfortu- nate, with rare exceptions, in the personality of its Sovereigns ; and that it has been caused through the greater part of the century with a disputed succession and with a “Legitimist ’ party which still issue manifestoes from its eyrie at Venice. The Carlists have been a muoh more dangerous thorn in the side of Spain than were ever the Jacobites in that of Hanoverian England; The Civil War, which was put down on the accession of Alfonso XII, was a far more serious affair than either the "Fifteen” or the 'Forty five.” The reign of the late King was too short for his persons! influence to have fair trial, bat it remains to be seen what a Sovereign of marked individua- lity of character, with the ability to make himself popular and the resolve to place the good of bis country before selfish indulgence, may effect. The young King has a clean slate before him. The loss of the colonies, though a cruel blow to the national pride, has removed an intolerable harden from the na- tional finance and from the military system. For many years past they had been little more than an open sore, and the drain of men and money had been increasing at an appalling rate. It will be interesting to see whether Spain will bow to the blow or will attempt territorial expansion in another direction. It will be extre- mely regrettable if the attention of the nation is one more diverted from its own development to projects of conquest over-seas. We believe that there is still a great future before the land of the Cid if only its great natural resources could ever be utilized and its people taught to forego some of their inveterate habits. It is extraordinary that with vast mineral riches at their very door the rulers of Spain should have contented themselves with exploiting the treasures of the Incas and the mines of Potosi. Spain possesses an invaluable national asset in its country population, hardy and frugal Its extraordinary history has shown it to be un- conquerable by any foreign Power, and to pos- sess in its invincible national pride a force which, under proper direction and with suit- able guidance, might give it once again a voice in the councils of Europe Yet there is an apathy, an ind donee, a blind conservation about the people themselves which seems to render them impervious to the modern spirit. What the country needs is wealth, and yet it neglects one obvious source which could not, one would think, be hurtful to its ‘amour propre,” and which would entail little labour or thought. The coast of Spain might become one of the great tourist resorts of Europe if the innkeepers would only take the trouble, and such a stream of gold might flow into the country as Alva once promised Philip the Second he would wring from the merchants of the Low Countries. The Spanish Riviera is infinitely superior in every point of natural beauty and attraction to its French rival i yet it is unknown and unknowable became there is scarcely a single hotel in it at which a civi- lised passenger can stay. It is the same all over the country, which, with its great natural beauty and wonderfully interesting associa- tions, is practically a terra incognita even to the travelled citizens of the world. The Spaniard, with all his reserve and pride, is not averse to the dollar of the tourist It rests with him whether it is to be permanently withheld.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Callte Plague
During the week ending on May 28, two cases of cattle plague were reported, both from Kagr Zayat.
Damietta's Crievanoes
On Sunday the deputation of Damiettans presented a petition to the Financial Adviser. The appeal is now under consideration.
Cabbary Dook.
It is officially notified that the Gabbary Dock (Alexandria) will be closed for one month from June 4th, whilst the accessory channel is being deepened by dredging.
Patient's Suicide
Driven to deperation by his sufferings, whcihc became unendurable, Kerkor Elias, a patient of Kasr-el-Aini Hospital, threw himself out of the window of his ward and so ended his life
Popular University
Signor Giovanni Mundula will deliver a lecture in Italian at the University on Satur- day net, commencing at 9.15 p.m., on "Tre Anniversari Storici (5 Maggio 1789-1821- 1860."" Entrance free.
The Late Maltre Albrecht

The Mixed Triaunals yesturday gave judg- ment in favour of the heirs of the late Maltre Albrecht, who was killed last year by a fall from a train near Samaloout. The heirs claimed £25,000 compensation but the Mixed Courts have only awarded the sum £10,000.
Wakfs Administration

The Wakfs Administration has decided to appoint Abdallah Effendi Hamid, a clerk in the Passport Office, as manager of the two Tekiehs of Mecca and Medina, with a salary of L.E. 30 per month. The appointment will be confirmed by the COuncil of the Wakfs at its next meeting.
Water for Ras-el-Bar

The Ministry of the Interior has asked the Towns and Buildings Department to draw up plans for the installation of a drinking water supply at Ras el Bar. Mains will be laid from Damietta, whence the supply will be derived, to Ras el Bar. It is hoped to have the water laid on by the end of the summer season.
A. L. M. & D. S.

Last night;s lecture at the Sailors and Sol- diers' Institute proved a great sucess, the subject, "Architecture and Progress," being amply illustrated alike by Mr. R. Williams' remarks and by his lantern slides. We shall deal with the lecture more fully at a later date. Mr. Gould, H.B.M.'s Consul-General, presided, and there was a full attendance.
"The Dance of Fire."

a sensation was provided on Saturday night at Masserini's Menagerie, which is performing behind the G.P.O., by the appearance of Mme Masserini in the "Dance of Fire," accom- panied by her pet lion and lioness, Sultan and Gyptis. The performance was witnessed by a large crowd on Sunday also. Two intrepid Alexandrian youths have been entertaining the audiences by entering the lions' cage alone.
Ship in Distress.

The Austrian steamer recins, of Fiume, which left Alexandria on SUnday for Syria in ballast, was sighted by Kom el Nadoura signalling station early this morning in tow of the British S.S. Braemar, of Leith. The vessel signalled the letters "F.T.R.," meaning "Light in ballast," and the Ports and Lights tug Megd was immediately sent to her assistance and took her in tow from the Braemar, bringing her into the harbour, while the latter vessel pro- ceeded on her way.
Italian Benevelent Society

At the annual genereal meeting of the Cairo Italian Benevolent Society, the MArquis di Soragna, Italian Consul, who was oin the chair, delivered an eloquent speech in commemora- tion of the late Felix Suares, who was president of the committee. Me. Viligiardi announced that M. Raphael Suares had been elected to replace the deceased and that he had made a donation of £400 to the society on his elec- tion. The meeting was adjourned in sign of mourning.
Ex-Empress of Sahara in Cairo.

A "relic" of the famous Empire which Jacques Lebaudy dreamed of founding in the snads of the Sahara is now in Cairo, where she has made a very successful debut at the Ambassadors. Lebaudy jilted her two years ago for an artiste of the Nouveautes during his stay in Egypt, and she was naturally indignant with his when he returned to Austria. Her remonstrances, however, elicited revolver-shots, which touched her slighlty and led to the "Emperor" being accorded the hospi- tality of the State. So after visiting several capitals, including Constantinople, the ex Em- press has decided to try her luck on the Cairo stage, as a means of support.

div.head: FRONTEIR COMMISSION
div.p: DELIMITATION BEGINS TO-DAY.
The Frontier Commission has arrived at Akaba and will commence its task to day in conjunction with the Turkish Commissioners

div.head: NEW LAND COMPANY
div.p: The estate, which is proposed should be taken over from the Behera Company by a new land company, is situated in the village of Teba, to the north of Kafr Sheikh. The Delta Light Railway Company is building a new line of railway which will end on the property itself. We hear that the land is of good quality and has a considerable future before it.

div.head: CAIRO HOTEL COMBINE
div.p: At the recent annual genreal meeting of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, the managing director, George Nungovich Bay, in reply to a question of a shareholder on the subject of the alleged hotel combine, stated that of any resolution had been taken on this subject it would have been communicated to the shareholders.

This statement in no way invalidates the news we gave in our issue of to-day week when we announced that there was a probability of an approaching fusion of the two most im- portant Cairo hotel companies, the george Nungovich Hotels Company and the Egyptian Hotels Company, and that Mr. Chas. Baehler and Nungovich Bay, managing directors of the two companies, would meet in London this summer to discuss the question.

Some ill-informed Cairo newspapers have ventured to contradict the news of the combine. We will merely ask them to also deny the fact that Nungovich Bay and Mr. Baehler intended to meet in London in the course of this summer to confer on the matter.

div.head: MOTOR TRACTION COMPANY
div.p: The statutes of the Eqyptian Motor Traction Company appear in yesturday's "Journal Officiel." The company has been formed with a capital of £60,000, divided into 15,000 shares of £4 each, which have been wholly sub- scribed by the promoters in the following proportions: Antoine E. Benachi, 1,750; Constantin J. Choremi, 1,750; Etienne Delta, 1,750; Richard F. Giglio, 1,875; Edgard F. Giglio, 1,875; Nicolas Paraskevas, 1,750; Alfred J. Suares, 1,750; Clement Suares, 2,500.
We understand that the motor omnibuses which the company will put on the streets of Alexandria are already on the way out and will be here shortly.

div.head: ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: NEXT SEASON'S OPERA PROSPECTS

Friday night, Fra Diavolo; Saturday night, Zaza: both good but not so satisfactory as Figoletto. Fra Diavolo had not been learnt and rehearsed so fully as would be La Boheme or such pieces. But it is most of it very pretty music, and amusing comedy. Signor Battani and Signa. di Spada were excellent. He has certainly a splendid voice and can command the utmost delicacy and ease, or if wanted great sonority, far more than enough even for the large hall of the Abbas Theatre. If only tbe Khedival Opera would engage such sin- gers! for Signora di Spada was charming in the 2nd act, and the part could not have been sung better.

Zaza is, we think, new to Cairo. The play one knows: it is more or less a Traviata in lower life, the music-hall favourite insead of the high demi-mondaine. One cannot but say, however, that it is far more consistent, and powerful, and free from the maudlin element of Dumas' production. The music! Well; what could it be but a rechuffe of Tosca &c., with snatches of Wagner, notably one long phrase straight from the 'Venus Berg' motif? All through the effect is rather coarse and "oppor- tunist," but one has to admit that it is in a way appropriate. Signor Carpi and again Siga. di Spada were the best, Siga. di Spada was particularly ecellent in her acting, and certainly in the first two acts in her dress and manner and everything else she bit the exact note. The chorus was very bad in the 3rd act behind the scene, but lively and natural in the first act. Signor Barterra is perhaps the only really unsatisfactory singer: he showed this in Lorenzo in Fra Diavolo as well as on this occasion as Malardot: his voice is thin and he sings flat, with far too much effort. Signor Arrighetti (Cascar) would be effective but for the persistent prolongation of his notes, which is very trying.

Yet on the whole company is more than satisfactory, and the Theartre Abbas is well worth going to. It would be well to say a word as to next year's prospects at the Khedival Threatre. Probably great promises will be held forth, but we heard on fairly good authority that as yet no dircetor has been engaged, and that no engagement will be made till the end of July result: not a single good artiste will be availabale, all having been engaged elsewhere long ago. It is said that the one most capable director who had offered his services refused for this very reason. So we must make up our minds to a repition of last year, - one or two "half" stars, anda crowd of others, doubtless worthy people in themselves, but quite un- known, and very far below the first or even the second class. When, if ever, shall we be allowed to have a voice in these matters? If we cannot have something good, at least, we might be told so at once instead of being lulled into accepting the pretentious and nondescript stuff for which we have the pleasure of paying, and out artistic patrons of receiving, such exorbitant sums.

div.head: THE EGUYPTAIN TRIBUTE
div.p: TERMINATION SUGGESTED

In the House of Commons last week, Dr. Rutherford asked whether, in view of recent occuracnces, the Government intended to re- vise the relations between Egypt and the Sultan of Turkey, and it so whether they would consider the desirability of terminating the Tribute.

Sir E. Grey: The Government do not desire to raise these questions. As a matter of fact, the Egyptian Tribute is entirely pledged to Britisih and foreign holders of Turkish Bonds, and is given direct to them.

div.head: ENGLAND AND THE PRORTE
div.p: QUESTIONS REGARDING THE TARIFF

In the House of Commons last Tueesday, Mr. Gooch asked whether, in view of the present temper of the Porte, His Majesty's Govern- ment would resist the increase of the Turkish Tariff till Lord Lansdowne's conditions involv- ing the administratice control of Macedonia by the Powers had been accepted

Sir Edward Grey replied that the question of the administration and control of Macedonia was settled by the institution of Internatio- nal Finanacial Commission which was accepted by the late Government. The assent of his Majesty's Government and the other Powers to the proposed increase of the Turkish Tariff would only be given subject to a sufficient guarantee that the proceeds would be applied to making goof the deficit on the Macedonian Budget.

div.head: FRANCE AND GERMANY.
div.p: ALLEGED INTRIGUES IN CAIRO.

"Al Ahram" is responsible for the statement that a member of the German Diplomatic Agency at Cairo is renewing his attmepts to persuade the Moroccan colony in Cairo to demand German protection. The chief members of this colony have for the last two years paid complimentary visits to the French Diplomatic Agency on the fete of July 14, and "Al Ahram" expects that the German Diplomatic Agent in question will do his utmost to dissuade them from doing so this year.

div.head: CYPRUS FOR GERMANY.
div.p: A curious statement affecting Cyprus ap- pears in the "Berliner Morgen Post," which says that an arragement is on the point of being concluded between Germany and Great Britain in regard to the Bagdad railway on the following basis: As fas as Bagdad the line shall be German; thence to the Persian Guld the railway shall be British, that is to say, under British control. In compensation for this concession England will allow Germany to occupy one of the Turkish islands - Cyprus or Rhodes.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: On the anniversary of the accession of the Sultan the first 722 kilometres of the Hedjaz line will be opened with much ceremony. The remainder of the 880 kilometres, towards the building of which special appeals have been made throughout the Moslem world, is ex- pected to be in full working order for the pilgrimage of 1908.

div.head: PLAGUE AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: A case of plague was notified at Alexandria to-day, the patient being a young man living at Gabbari who was isolated on suspicion on Sunday. In consequence of this case or plague, the ususal vexations quarantine restrictions on the departure of vessels have been reimposed in the harbour.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is expected to return from his trip in the Western Desert on Thursday.
His Highness will spend Friday at Montazah, where he will attend midday prayer.
On Saturday morning the Khedive's fare- well reception will be held at Ras-el-Tin Palace; and on the same day the Council of Ministers will meet under his Highness's presidency.

div.head: BRISTISH CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The action brought by Spino Ellul against Messrs. Festa and Combo came before the British Consular Court, Cairo, this morning. Mr. Festa announced that he had come to an arragement with the palintiff, and the hearing of the action brough against Mr. Cumbo for the recovery of certain moneys was adjourn- ed till Friday next.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Avoca (Wescott and Laurence Line) left Malta yesturday, and is due here on Friday next with general cargo from Antwerp and London.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: NOTED FOR ITS EXCELLENT CUISINE.
ELECTRIC LIGHT. LIFT.
Special terms for officers of the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex presses by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits — free discussion. OUR CONSULAR SERVICE. REPLY TO “XENOS.” To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette.” Dear Sir,—Here area few observations in regard to “ Xenos’ ” letter as far as the Levant is concerned:— The necessary qualifications for a Consol are more numerous than he would appear to imagine. Mere commercial knowledge is nothing—if it is rot backed by a know ledge of the language and history of the locality to which he is appointed, as wide an education as he can acquire, and certain qualities, such as tact and good manners, which are valuable even in these days of strenuous and uncultured efficiency. As to the Consoler reports, “Xenos” will find, if he takes the trouble to study recent reports from various towns in the Ottoman Empire, a great improvement in the com- mercial information which they contain. Mach remains to be done in this respect, but good beginning has been made. Then comes the question, should a Consul he a diplomatist or not ? “Xenos” remarks that the Turkish authorities have more than once regarded Consular interference in the Lebanon, Armenia, and Macedonia “in the light if political intrigue.” Well, Sir, what does it matter if they do so regard it ? If sensible Consul can stop a riot, mitigate the cruelty of the local authorities, or protest against some peculiarly scandalous act of oppression or corruption on their part, so mnoh the better. Really, after the recent performance's of the Porte, “Xenos” is a little too considerate for the feelings of that sublime abstraction which takes the responsibility for Sultan Abdul Hamid’s acts Personally I think one might solve the difficulty by appointing a certain number of purely commercial consular assistants to each consulate-general, if our trade is really in each a bad way. But I am a little sceptical ; and if there is any menace to our com- merce in the Levant it appears to me to be largely the fault of our home merchant?, who send out travelers who often cannot speak any language but English—and that often incorrectly -and then do not trouble act on the recommendations of these worthies. Finding themselves losing ground through their own slackness and want of imagination they then howl to the Govern- ment to help them. Civis. Cairo, 28th May.

div.head: The State Railways
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.” Sir, -A few weeks ago you published an extract from L^rd Cromer’s Report quoting the opinion of an English Railway Director as to the working of the State Railways. We have had some experience of the delays on these lines and have suffered and arp still suffering loss in consequence. It takes three, four, and , even five days to get delivery of goods from Alexandria. There is no sense in such delays —no third-rate Railway Company in England or even on the Continent would be tolerated to so delay delivery. As the E.R.A. holds the monopoly it should be compelled to give effi- cient service. We protest against the English Railway official referred to whitewashing the E.R.A. and do not believe that he had enquir- ed of any traders at Cairo or elsewhere or he would not have reported so favorably. Every- body depending for their supplies on the rail- way transit has had to suffer owing to its inefficient management. John Jones & Co. Mansoorah, May 28.

div.head: Port Said Sporting Club
div.p: To the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazbtti.” I Sir, — Many readers of your valuable paper were pleaded to see this mild protest of “The Woman who Knows” in your last Satarday’s issue re the feature(?) New Sporting Club of our town. But, Mr. Editor, there is no valid reason why there should be a Sporting Club of this character at Port Said, when we are so much in need of a public garden in which our children, and even the parents, could find some recreation, which would somewhat break the monotony of the everlasting walks upon the sand. A Sporting Club would only mean—not merely a delight to Schweppe’s —but a standing advertisement for the leading whisky firms, and also entertainment for a few selfish residents. The ridocuous idea of a Sporting Club emanated from the brain of a former Govern- ment official, and on his departure it was hoped the scheme would have been abandoned. To some extent a douche was applied, but agree- ing with the sentiment of ‘'The Woman who Knows,” it would take a tidal wave to stir up any same enthusiasm here, and as yon no doubt are aware snob a phenomenon as a tidal wave is unknown in the Mediterranean. It remains to be seen whether the Red Sea could afford os any assistance in this line. The Government were kind enough to pre- sent the inhabitants with the land, and it was first suggested to raise public subscriptions with a view to establishing a Sporting Club, bnt it is understood the subscriptions aid not come along an freely as was anticipated. To have anything worthy of consideration at all, whether it be a Sporting Club, or a public garden, it would require an outlay of say £2/3,000 at a minimum and this amount will never, I venture to say, be collected from the residents at Port Said as most of them are here with the one idea of making as much money as possible with the final aim to leave and enjoy the remainder of their lives in their native countries and therefore do not take more than a passing interest. In my opinion the test thing possible would be for the Government to take the entire affair in hand, and erect a public garden under their control. I feel confident that the expressions contained in this letter have the full sym pathy of the majority of the Port Said resi dents.-I am, etc, Old Resident. Port Said, May 29.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB
div.p: HANDICAP TENNIS TOURNAMENT. The annual handicap tennis tournament will be held at the Alexandria Sporting Club, commencing about the 12th Jane, when the following handicap events, open to members, will be contested : (1) Ladies’ Singles, (2) Men’s Singles, (3) Ladies’ Doubles, (4) Mens Doubles, (5) Mixed Doubles. Entries for these events will close on the 7th June and mast be sent in to Mr. J.B. Cornish, Junr., 4, Rue Gare de Ramleh, Alexandria, accompanied by entrance fees, which are P.T. 20 for each player for each event. The result of the drawing and the handicaps will be duly published in the “ Egyptian Gazette ” and also posted np at the Sporting Club, together with the notice of the regula- tions and the dates for the conclusion of the different rounds. Prizes will be given to the winners of each event. No event will take place unless there are at least four entries in the doable, and six entries in the single events. The results of the open tennis tournament are as follows :— Men’s Singles. Winner, J. Guarino ; second, J. E. Cornish, Jr. Men’s Doubles. Winners, T. H. Marsden and H. Thomas ; second, W. Cumming and J. H. Percival. Mixed Doubles. Winners, Mrs. J. H. Percival and J. E. Cornish ; second, Mrs. and W. Cumming.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p:
We regret to report the slight illness of Mustapha Pacha Fuhmy, who has been con- fined to his bed for the last two days. General Thurneyssen Pacha, A.D.C. to the Khedive, leaves Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd steamer on Saturday next en route for Vienna, where he will await the arrival of his Higness after his visit to Constantinople. Izzet Pacha leaves for Athens on Wednesday to sign the Commercial Convention between the Greek and the Egyptian Governments. Slatin Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, will leave Khartoum for Cairo about the beginning of June. His Excellency will remain for a few days in the Capital before going to Europe on leave. Lady Victoria Machell left Port Said last night for home. Mr. Dupuis, Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan, arrived in Cairo yesterday from Khartoum. Surg. Captain Purdy, M.D., F.R.G.S., of the New Zealand Militia, has been granted further extension of leave of absence whilst serving in the Egyptian Quarantine Service. Capt. T. G. Dalby, K. R R. C., has joined the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi. Lieut. L. Bansfield, R. À. M. C., has also joined the Egyptian Army with the same rank. The following officers have been granted three months’ leave of absence, on private affairs : Brevet-Col. C. M. Edwards, Major E. S. C. Hobson, Capt. R A. A. de Salis, D S O.,Lient. D’A. H. Kay, C. H. Kitching, R. W. Pepys, P. T. Bull, 4th Worcestershire Regiment; Major R. Percy Smith, R.G.A. Emir Mohamed Arslan, son of Emir Mus- tapha Arslan, the chief of the Druses of Mount Le ban on. has been appointed counsellor to the Turkish Embassy in Belgrade, where he has held the position of first secretary during the last few years. The birthday of the Rev. Father Cotel was celebrated on Saturday by the pupils-past and present-of the Collège de la Sainte Famille, Cairo, who gave a most amusing performance of Un Voyage en Chine. M. de la Boulinière presided at the fête, aud among others present were Lord Cromer, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mgr. Aurelio Briante, the Sub-Governor of Cairo, M. Cambon, M. Do nap, Père Duret and many of the clergy, MM. de Gorostarzu, Lamba, Tous- saint, Caneri, Privat, and many others. M. Basile G. Bonnias, physician, and M. Stelianos Golis, pharmacist, have been antho- rised to practise in Egypt The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleb:—Coles Pacha and Mrs. Coles, Cairo; Mr. C. Brown, London; Mrs. H. Hornik and family,/Cairo ; Mrs. A. Tede8chi, Helonan ; Mr. Taylor, Dr. and Mrs. Madden and family, Mr. F. Fondor, Mr. R. Rolo, Cairo ; Mr. and Mrs. Limpritis, Miss L. Limpritis, Mr. and Mrs J. Watson, Alexandria ; Mr. and Mrs. R. Springer and family, Helonan; Mrs. 0. Katenzki, Mrs. A. Rasohke, Mr. L. Petter, Vienna ; Mr. and Mrs. Calambrokidis, Alexandria ; Mrs. H. Fr&odagar, Lyons ; Mr. 0. Lenz, Cairo.
TO PROTECT THE SUEZ CANAL. Althongh it has been decided by the Admi- ralty to abolish the naval command of the Cape of Good Hope and West Coast of Africa Squadron, and to reduce the naval strength in the waters from the Red Sea to the Cape, yet in view of the dangers to which, in time of war, the Sort Canal mast be exposed, it will be essential to keep the dockyard at Simonstown—upon which large sums have been spent—in such a condition that its staff may be expanded without delay in case of hostilities occurring of a character likely to lead to its being required for the docking and repair of the largest men-of war whioh extended operations may take into these waters. As no other nation keeps any men-of-war in the vicinity of the Cape of Good Hope, the possibility of naval actions thereabouts is remote. The nearest foreign squadron is a small French one based on Madagascar.

div.head: NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD.

div.head: LAND & MORTGAGE OF EGYPT
div.p:
The twenty-sixth annual general meeting of the shareholders of the Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, Limited, was held on the 18th inst. at the Cannon-street Hotel, E.C., under the presidency of Sir Edward Leigh Pem berton, K.C.B. (the chairman of the company.) The Secretary (Mr. J. Chisholm) having read. the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors, The Chairman said : It often happens that the chairman of a company has to apologise to his shareholders for the dulness and monotony of his annual addresses, bat it is seldom tho case that he can excuse that monotony by attributing it to uninterrupted success ; but that is my position. I don't suppose that at any time in the chequered career of Egypt that country has been in a better state socially or financially than at the present moment. You arc aware that quite recently the Sultan at Constantinople was said to be very aggressive and to threaten to annex some part of the property of Egypt ; but I think his attention was confined to the peninsula of Sinai, and there is no reason to think that any of the lands in mortgage to our company are in dan- ger, and we may consider our position in that respect tolerably secure. The position of Egypt muBt be very satisfactory to you an Englishmen and not less so as shareholders in this company and, though its flourishing condition has attracted an enormous volume of adventure, including, of coarse, much competition with oar own enterprise, there is still, we think, room for us all, and we are glad to see attention given to business in Egypt.There has never been so much speculation in land—sales and re-sales are constantly made, and each time at an advanced price. How loDg the advance may be, nobody can tell ; but we don’t buy land ; we only help others to buy it, and help those to develop it who have already got it ; and, if coarse, the increased value of the land enhan ces the margin of our security. I believe we could advantageously place a larger amount of capital than we have got, but as our funds are limited we have endeavored to make the most of what we have got. We hive therefore deter- mined, as you are aware, to convert, as far as we can, the existing debentures, which are paid off by annual drawings and bear interest at 4$ and 5 per cent, into debenture stock bearing interest at 4 per cent.,and to issue the balance over the total of the existing debentures, and amounting to £17,200, as debenture stock. This sum was very largely oversubscribed aDd has been allotted, and the amount converted is satisfactory ; and as each annual drawing takes place, the sam paid will be re-issued at 4 per cent., instead of 4.5 or 5 per cent I think 1 told you last year that the amount of capital then invested was £593,64$, being the largest sam employed by the company since its founda- tion -that was on March 81, 1905 ; on March 31, 1906, it was £598,232, showing an increase of £1,584. The new loans, as well as the old ones, are, as Mr. Hari reports, safe and on very good security, and the general condition of the business is as good as it was in the record year, 1905. As to the rate of interest on oar invest- ments, it has, as we anticipated, diminished bat in a very trifling degree, and it still amounts to something over 7 per cent. Of course, we could not expect to maintain oar old rate in face of the competition we have to meet ; but we look to the increased volume of business and to the reduced rate of interest we onrsel- ves pay to restore the balance and enable us to continue the payment of £10 per cent, to oar shareholders. I am sorry Mr. Hari is not here to-day, as he was at our last annual meeting ; but he is busy at work on the spot, where all our real work is done, and where I daresay be is better employed ; but I am sure that the shareholders will feel and express, as the direc- tors do, their deep sense of the gratitude they owe to him for the continued satisfactory con- dition of their affairs. (Applause.)
I will now turn to the accounts. You will see that the gross earnings for the year amount to £45,900, as against £44,291 last year, being an increase of £1,609. The net earnings this year were £18,196, as against £17,089 last year, showing an increase of £1,113. From the gross earnings of £45,900 we have deducted the total expenditure, which includes the interest on the debenture bonds. To the net earning-! of the year, £18,196, is to be added the balance brought forward from last year of £2,139 odd, making together a total of £20,335 19s, 6d. From this we deduct the interim dividend paid last November at the rate of 10 per cent., amounting to £7,500, leaving a credit balance of £12,835 19s. 6d. Oat of this we have placed £3,000 to reserve for contingencies, leaving available a balance of £9,835 19a. 6d. We recommend a dividend of 5 per cent, for the past six months, which, with the 5 per cent, paid in November, will make up a dividend of 10 per coat, for the year This wi'l absorb £7,500, leaving the sum of £2 335 19s. 6d. to be carried forward. I think you will consider this a very satisfactory state of affairs, and if you are good enough, as I hope you will be, to pass the report and accounts, the dividend will be issued to day. I now beg to move : "That the report and accounts submitted to this meeting be, and are hereby, received and adopted, and that, as recom- mended by the board, a dividend of 10 per cent. per annum on the paid-up share capital of the company for the year ended March 31 last, consisting of the interim dividend of 5 per cent, for the six months ended September 30 paid by the board on account in November last and 5 per cent, for the six months ended March 81 last, be, and is hereby, declared, free of income tax.” (Applause.) The Right Hou. Visoount Hampden.G.C.M.G., seconded the motion. Mr. Skeel : You said yoa could easily place satisfactorily more capital than yoa have got, and, as one of the original shareholders who

thoroughly appreciates the fact that yon have taken us out of troublous times and brought us into a happy condition, I should like to say that I have got confidence in you, and if you wanted additional capital I think you have only got to say so and the share holders will subscribe all that may be requir- ed. Then I should like to say 1 think yon might rest and be thankful with the amount you have placed to reserve, and that if things go on as they appear to be doing, if yon do not like to raise the dividend of 10 per cent, you might pay us a bonus. Sir Walter F. Miéville, K.C.M.G. (director): We are quite with you about the reserve ; but this year you must take the result as excep- tional. In the old days, and with the auditors’ consent, we used to put on the credit side of the balance sheet the expenses for the issue r>f debentures, and write them off little by little, aDd I am afraid that, as a share holder, not then being a director, I used to say that it was a bogus asset We have had to pay 2 1/2 per cent, and 2 per cent, to people who have come in with the five per cents, and two and-a-half per cents., and we want to pay off the expenses connected with the de- bentures, so that when the time comes—if it does come—that the rate of interest goes down in Egypt, we should be in a position to borrow money at 4 per cent, net, without any "bogus assets” on the other side. We have got the cleanest balance-sheet possible, and we want to keep it. The Chairman : It is only a matter of se- curity, as you see. The motion was then pat and unanimously agreed to. The Chairman moved the re-election of Viscoant Hampden as a director, remarking that he was one of the original directors. Mr. R. C. Johnston seconded the motion, which was carried unanimously, and, on the motion of the Chairman, seconded by S r Walter Miéville, Mr. N. Stanhope Stott, the other director retiring, was also re-elected. Messrs. Dartnall moved the reappointment of Messrs. Price, Waterhouse and Co., as auditors, which was seconded by Mr.West and carried unanimously. A vote of thanks was accorded the chairman and directors for their services during the year, and a similar compliment was paid to the staff, with special mention of the service! of Mr. Hari.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Lundi 28 Mai. Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres est à 3 1/8 et non pas à 3 1/8 pont cent, comme cela avait été annoncé avant-hier par suite, assurément, d’une erreur de transmission télé- graphique. Samedi passé, aa Stock Exchange, le Con- solidé anglais est resté invarié à 89 3/4, de môme que l’Unifiéa à 104 1/4. La National Bank a clôturé en hausse de 1/4 à 26 3/8, l’Agricole de 1/8 à 10 la Daïra et la Delta Light de 1/8 également à 17 3/8 et 12 1/4. A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien s'est maintenue h 772. La Banque d'Athènes a réactionné de 1 franc à 150.
Ainsi que o’était à prévoir, notre marché des valeurs a, plus ou moins maintenu sa tendance à la fermeté. L’ouverture de la séance a été très animée, spécialement sur les Delta Land et les Hooker par suite de la confirmation do la fusion des deux Sociétés. Bon mouvement aussi sur les Baehler, étayé sur la nouvelle que le bénéfice net de la Société pour l’exercice écoulé a’élèveraitt à L.E. 51,000, alors que celui de la Nungovich Hotels Co. n’a été que d’environ la moitié de cette somme. Ou fait, de plus, entrer eu ligue de compte que les obligations de la Société se trouveraient actuellement remboursées du chef des condi- tions delà vente de 18,000 mètres de terrain da domaine de Ghrzireh ; en oatre, la Com- pagnie resterait intéressée dans l’affaire. Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, qui s’était maintenue à sou prix d’avant hier, a été rame ée eu clôture à 26 3/16. L’Agrico’e est renée à 9,7/8. Le Comptoir Financier Best inscrit à 6 l’action ancienne et 5 7/8 la nouvelle. L’action Immobilière a faib'i à 372-373; par contre, la part de fondateur est remontée à 600. L’aotion Agricole du Ni! a gagné 10 francs à 270 ; la part de fondateur a perdu 1/4 à 7 1/4. Eu bonne tendance l’ÜDion Fonoière a fait 6 5/8 pour clôturer à 6 19/32. La Nile Land a rattrapé 1/8 k IV 1/8 ; la part de fondateur a cotée 92. Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont faibli à 16 l’action ancienne ; l’action nou- velle s’est raff rœia k 15 3/: 6 1/4. Lis Baehler ont haussé jusqu'à 5 5/8 pour finir à 5 1/2 9/16. Les Upper Egypt ont progressé à 4 1/2 Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta ont été poussés jusqu’à 4 7/16 pour olôturer à 4 5/16- 3/8. Les Hooker ont atteint 1 5/32 et fini à 1 1/8. Les Oasis ont été échangés à 1 1/8. La Kbe divial Mail a avancé à 31 t>h. 6. La part de fondateur Estates a perda 3/16 à 10 1/8.
La septième assemb’ée ordinaire de la Nun- govich Hotels Co. a été tenue avant hier au Grand Continental. Il ressort du rapport da conseil qn’apres prélèvement d’une somme d’environ L.E. 15.000 pour réparations, frais d’exploitation et d’admi- mistration, amortissement d'obligations et solde des frais d e premier établissement, il est resté un bénéfice net de L.E. 25,481. Après prélèvement d’an premier dividende de 5 % pour 27,000 notions, de 10 % pour les administrateurs, il a été décidé de distribuer

sur le soldo un dividende complémentaire de 15 % et de reporter à nonvean LE. 2,317. Un actionnaire a demandé des explications sur les rameurs propagées relativement à la venta da Grand Continental, les dispositions spéciales qui auraient été prises pour le Mena House et l’Hôtel Casino de SanStefano, le pro- jet de transformation de la Société, etc. Le président a habilement répondu que si qaelqne résolution avait été prise sur ces points, le conseil n’eût pas manqué de la corn muniqner snx actionnaires. * Nous détachous d’une lettre de Londres, en date du 20 Mai, les lignes suivantes concer- nant la situation monétaire : "Malgré toutes les apparences contraires, la tention monétaire persiste ici, car non seulement la place de New York est toujours mal ponrvue, mais on s’y attend à la prolongation de cet état do choses. La preuve en est qu’une des plus grandes et des plus fortes Compagnies amé ricaines de chemins de fer a décidé de créer pour ses besoins urgents des bons à 4 1/2 pour cent à 18 mois de date et de les offrir à un prix légèrement inférieur an pair. "En dépit des abaissements transitoires qui pourraient se produire dans le taux de l'escompte privé, il faudra doue a’accontn- mer à l’idée que le grand réservoir de Londres sera menacé pendant quelque temps encore, et l’argent do saurait être à bon marché an dehors s’il reste cher ici. De même, la tonne des Bour- ses, à commeucer par le Stock Exchange, souffrira da prix élevé des reports. Aussi bien le conrs da Consolidé ne pont s’élever si le report courant est à 5 %.
Suivant des informations de Londres le dividende qui sera proposé poor l'exercice 190 par le Conseil d’administration à la pro chaine assemblée générale ordinaire de la Ban qne Impériale Ottomane sera de 8 pour cent on 16 sh. par action, contre 7 % pour l’exercice précédent.

Les Tramways d’Alexandrie faiblissent à 191 et les divider des à 340. Les Egyptians Markets sont à 26/3. La Cassa di Sconto gagne frs. 0,50 à 215, les Lots tares 1 franc à 145. div.head: The Nile Cold Storage Company, Ltd.
div.p:
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Ni’e Cold Storage Company, Limited, will be held at the offices of tin Cairo Water Company, Sharia Boulac, Cairo, Egypt, on Wednesday, he 6th day of Jane, 1906, at five o’clock in the afternoon, when the subjoined Resolutions, which ware passed at an Extraordinary General Meeting held on Saturday, the 19th day of May, 1906, will be submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions.
RESOLUTIONS. 1. That the Director« be hereby authorized to take the necessary legal steps to reduce the Capital ( f the Company from £50,000 to £10,000 sterling, reducing each fully paid Ordinary Share from 20/- to 16/- fully paid, and reducing each fully paid Deferred Share from 1/ to 9 2/5d. (or some approximate sam) fully paid : and that, the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company be altered accordingly. 2. That the Directors be hereby authorised to effect an agreement as between the Company and the Holders of the Deferred Shares, whereby the latter shall have the right to thirty five per cent. of the surplus profits after payment out of such profits of eight per cent. per annum on the Ordinary, shares in place of one-half thereof as provided in clause one of Article 5 of the Articles of Association of the Company, the right to forty per cent. of the reserve fund accumul- ated out of such surplus profits in place of one-half thereof as provided in clause two of the same Article, and the right to forty per cent. of the surplus assets in place of one half thereof as provided in clause three of the same Article : and that Article 5 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered accordingly namely: That the word ’half” after the word "the right to” in the sixth line of Article five be struck oat and the words “thirty- five per cent. of” substituted therefor: and that the word "one-half be similarly struck out from the sixteenth and twenty-third lines of the same Article and the words "forty per cent” substituted therefor in each instance. HOLDERS of SHARE WARRANTS to BEARER are requested to deposit same with either of the following Banks, viz : — The National Bank of Egypt The Bank of Egypt The Anglo-Egyptian Bank Tin Imperial Ottoman Bank The Crédit Lyonnais or at the Offices of the Company either in London or Cairo at least three days before the date of the Meeting. The receipt tor shares deposited mast le produced at the Meeting. Dated this 26th day of May, 1906. By order of the Board, W. H. PERKINS, 28002-2-2 Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: TO-DAY’s TELEGRAMS.
div.p: UPROAR IN THE REICHSTAG GERMANY AND HER COLONIES. REBUFF TO GOVERNMENT. Berlin, May 28. The Reichstag has practically rejected the whole of the Supplementary Estimates for South West Africa and subsequently refused the Government the necessary money to estab- lish a Ministry of the Colonies. This severe rebuff to the Government is mainly due to a hectoring speech of Colonel Deimling, who has just been appointed to the command in South Africa. He lectured the Reichstag in a stentorian voice as if he were giving orders to troops on the drill-ground, declaring his determination to ignore certain recommenda- tions of the Budget Committee unless otherwise directed by the Emperor, who, he said, alone bad to decide. A tremendous uproar ensued. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN UNREST.
div.p: PROMISCUOUS BOMB THROWING. St. Petersburg, May 28. Bombs have been thrown at the Governor- General of Tiflis and the Chief of Police. They escaped unhurt, bat a Cossack was killed. A number of bombs were thrown in the square, in Sevastopol, daring a review, on the occasion of the anniversary of the coro- nation. Three persons were killed and many injured, including the Governor of tin fortress and the Chief of Police. (Reuter)

div.head: A CITY EN FETE.
div.p: THE SPANISH MARRIAGE. Madrid, May 28. The city is crammed to overflowing with foreign princes and missions : every nation is represented. They will all figure in the proces- sion to the church, lending an exceptional eclat to the proceedings, and will occupy £6 state carriages, mostly historical. A ball-fight on an extraordinary scale will be the leading feature of the fêtes. (Renter)

div.head: HOPE FOR IRELAND.
div.p: MR. BRYCE’S LOAN BILL. London, May 28. House of Commons.—With a view to ar- resting the physical decline of the population and instilling new hope into Irish labourers Mr. Bryce has introduced a Bill authorising a loan of £4 5PO.OOO to provide 25,000 labourers’ cottages in Ireland and devoting £50,000 annually, derived from various economies, to the same object. (Reuter)

div.head: EDUCATION BILL.
div.p: CHAMBERLAIN AMENDMENT REJECTED. London, May 28. Mr. Chamberlain’s amendment to tho Edu- cation Bill has been rejected by 367 votes to 172. (Reuter)

div.head: CHINESE CUSTOMS.
div.p: AWAITING CHINA’S REPLY. London, May 28. House of Lords. — Lord Fitzmaurice stated that China’s reply to the last Note on the Customs question was expected in a very short time The Government, he said, did not intend to allow a protracted delay in the settlement of this question, fully realising its importance to trade. They were acting with the knowledge of the other Powers and in perfect harmony with them. (Reuter)

div.head: EMPEROR OF CHINA ILL.
div.p: Peking, May 28. The usual spring diplomatic audiences have been postponed indefinitely owing to the illness of the Emperor, who has been in had health for some months ; his condition, however, is not believed to be critical. (Reuter)

div.head: THE BANK OF MOROCCO.
div.p: Paris, May 28. The international committee appointed to draw up the statutes of the Morocco Bank will meet on the 30th ins. under the presi- dency of M. Pallain. (Havas)

div.head: BELGIAN ELECTIONS.
div.p: Brussels, May 28. In the results of the elections the Catholics retain the majority in the Chamber. (Havas)

div.head: •A HISTORY OF EGYPT.
div.p: The publication of such a book as that under notice is highly significant of the growing interest in Egypt now shown by our American cousins, and following as it does tho discoveries made by trans-Atlantic explorers in this country during recent years, affords another proof of the high standard of know ledge and experience gained by the United States Egyptologists. England seems at the present time to he keeping somewhat in the background, and we have only to instance the fact that it was an Italian professor who was recently appointed to the post of Curator of the Alexandria Museum. and that the history of the Cairo Museum makes no mention of any Englishman of the pro- minence of M. Maspero, Mariette Pacha, M. de Morgan, and others whose names are familiar in connection with that great undertaking, to prove that we are lagging behind very con- siderably in the work of unveiling the glories of Egypt’s past history. Professor Breasted not only presents his Hots in a very attractive and interesting manner, bat as he says in his preface, he has aimed above everything at accuracy. noting that “although many ex- haustively accurate publications of hiero- glyphic documents now appear with every year, it is nevertheless true that the large majority of standard Egyptian documents access la in publications exhibit a degree of incompleteness and inaccuracy not, in the author’s judgment, to be found in any other branch of epigraphic science. “Under these circumstances the author’s first obligation has been to go behind the publications to the original monument itself in every possible instance. This task has consumed years and demanded protract- ed sojourn among the great collections of Europe.” How far the author has succeeded in making ancient Egyptian history clearer than hereto- fore only a savant can pretend to say, but the many exquisite photographs taken direct from the temples at Thebes and other places should certainly be of great value to the Egyptologist, and these form one of the most valuable features of the work. “Egyptian arcbæology,” says the author, “is in its infancy, and but few of the fundamental studies and researches already completed in classical arohæology have been made in this province.” And, referring to early forms of religion he says, “The study of Egyptian religion has but began, and decades will pass before even the preliminary special studies shall have been completed.........” To the author’s contributions on the subject of reli- gion we shall refer later on. It was with some feeling of disappointment that we found on opening the hook and read ing its early chapters, no attempt to elucidate the story of Egypt in prehistoric times. Pro- fessor Flinders Petrie gave us in the first volume of his History of Egypt much valuable information in this direction, and we hope that some day we shall know far more than we do at present of the Stone Age and the races who fashioned the carved stones lying about everywhere which still bear traces of the original designs made on them in the remote ages. This by the way. Our author evidently considers the historic ages as of more importance and devotes himself to them, making but slight reference even to the early pottery of the remote ages or the anceint burial p'aces found in the valley of the Nile. But from the point from which he takes up the history of the country np to the fall of Psamtik III., with which the volume ends, the author gives us fact on fact of the utmost interest to the tourist, the Bible student, and the professional scholar, embodying as he does the results df the very latest researches. The following passage is deeply interesting, giving as it doss an insight into the science of “Earliest Egypt:” — Already in the forty third century B. C the men of the Delta had discovered the year of three hundred and sixty five days and they introduced a calendar year of this length beginning on the day when Sirius rose at sunrise, as determined in the lati- tude of the southern Delta, where these earliest astronomers lived, in 4241 B. C It is the civilization of the Delta, therefore which furnishes us with the earliest fixed dates in the history of the world. The in- vention and introduction of this calendar is surprising evidence of the advanced col- tore of the age and locality to which it belongs. No ration of antiquity, from the earliest times through classic European history, was ab!e to devise a calendar, which should evade the inconvenience re- sulting from the fact that the lunar month and the solar year are incommensurable quantities, the lunar months being incon- stant and also not evenly dividing the solar year. This earliest known calendar, with an amazingly practical insight into the needs to b9 subserved by a calendar abandoned the lunar month altogether and substituted for it a conventional month of thirty days. Its devisers were thus the first people to perceive that a calendar must be an artificial device, entirely di- vorced from nature save in the acceptance of the day and tho year. They therefore divided the year into twelve of those thirty day months, and a sacred period of five feast-days, intercalated at tho end cf tho year. The year began on that day when Sirius first appeared on the eastern horizon at sunrise, which in our calendar was on the nineteenth of July. But as this calendar year was in reality about

*A History of Egypt from the Earliest Time to the Persian Conquest, by James Henry Breasted, Ph.D., Professor of Egyptology and Oriental History in the University of Chicago. New York: Charles Scribner’s Sons. Price $5.

a quarter of a day shorter than the solar year, it therefore gained a fall day every four years, thus slowly revolving on the astronomical-year thus passing entirely around it once in fourteen, hundred and sixty years, only to begin the revolution again. An astronomical event like the heliacal rising of Sirius, when dated in terms of the Egyptian calendar, may therefore be computed and dated within four years in terms of our reckoning, that is, in years B. C. This remarkable calendar, already in use at a remote age, is the one introduc- ed into Rome by Julius Cæsar, as the most convenient calendar then known, and by the Romans it was bequeathed to us. It has thus been in use uninterruptedly over six thousand years. We owe it to the men of the Delta Kingdom, who lived in the forty-third century B. C. ; and we should notice that it left their hands in much more convenient form, with its twelve thirty day months, than after it had suffer- ed irregular alteration in this respect at the hands of the Romans. It would he scarcely fair to Prof. Breasted, even did oar limited space permit us to do so, to quote at length mach of the inte- resting matter with which the pages of this work are filled. The old Kingdom, the Middle Kingdom, the Hyksos, the Empire, first and second periods, the Decadence. the Restora- tion and the end are all folly treated of in this elaborate book of over 60) pages, which - ‘The Biblical World” declares to be “The best single-volume history of Egypt yet published.” We hope to resume oar notice of some of its contents at an early date. (To be continued)

div.head: THE RECENT DISCOVERIES AT OXYRHYNCHUS.
div.p: Referring to the recent discoveries at Oxyrhynchus, the “Daily Telegraph” says :— Once more Dr. Grenfell, and Dr. Hunt have made valuable discoveries in the mounds of Oiyrhynchus, quite equal in importance to those which so fascinated the world of schelar- ship nine years ago. The Egyptian Exploration Fund has done wonders already, especially in reference to those so-called “Logia”—“the sayings of our Lord”-one of which at least has a strange and unique value. In 1897, out of a mass of papyri dog out of the rains of Oxyrhynchus, which was one of the chief early Christian centres in Egypt, and is situated some one hundred and twenty miles sooth of Cairo, was extracted a fragment containing eight sayings of the Lord. What exactly they constituted has been much debated by scholars since. Harnack maintains that they come from the lost Gospel of the Egyptians ; others suggest that they are excerpts from a primitive Gospel —probably written in Hebrew in the first in- stance ; while others, again, speak of them as though they formed part of a sort of original nucleus of the four canonical Gospels. Most of the eight ‘‘sayings” added little or nothing to what we possess, bat the one numbered five was of first-rate interest and importance a strange text, in which Christ, possibly in a spirit of Pantheism, says, “Raise the stone and there thou shalt find Me, cleave-the wood and there am I.” To these “sayings” is now added a fresh and highly-interesting contribu- tion. Amongst the newest finds of Doctors Grenfell and Hunt is a vellum leaf, forty-five lines in all, from the manuscript of a lost Gospel. The subject, we are told, is a visit of. Jesus, with his disciples, to the Temple at Je- rusalem, and an encounter with a Pharisee who rebukes Christ and his followers because they have omitted the necessary and proper cere- monial of purification before entering the Holy j Place, and our Lord replies with a discourse on the difference between external and in- ternal parity. This, of coarse, is not dissi- milar from what we already have, both in the Gospels of Matthew and Luke ; bat we are told that in the new fragment there are several words not found in the New Testament, while the writer displays a considerable fami- liarity with Jewish customs, and also with the topography of the Temple at Jerusalem. The nature and value of the Gospel from which this passage comes we do not know, nor can more be said on the subject until the fresh Oxyrhynchus papyri are published next year. But this is not the only valuable element in the new discoveries. There la a fragment from Pindar—a novel form pf composition for the Theban bard, for it consists of odes of suppli- cation or thanksgiving, addressed to a god, and not a pæan, such as those with which tire are familiar, in honour of some athletic victor. There is also a part of a tragedy on the subject of Hypsipyle, supposed to be by Euripidies; and strangely enough, a part of a new history of Greece has been unearthed, which, it is hoped, will throw fresh light on the Pelopnnesisan war. Some of these manuscripts, dating from the second or third century, but thrown away, apparently, in the fifth century, belonged, it is clear, to an owner of a library, an among them are, we are told, fragments of Sappho and Bacchylides. So strange and wonderful has been the harvest of treasures due to the unre- bitting care and zeal of these modern dis- coverers, that we find ourselves, in the opening years of the twentieth century, not only adding to the scanty store of Greek literature, but, in some cases, actually revising the literary judg- meant of old classical scholars.

div.head: Societe COmmerciale d'Egypte
div.p: Messuieurs les actionnaires de la Societe Commerciale d'Egypte sont precenus que, con- forment a l'art. 20 des Statuts de la Societe une assemblee generale ordinaire aura lieu le 30 Juin 1906, a 4 h. de relevee, au siege de la Societe a Alexandria. Ordre Du Jour: 1.-Rapport du Conseil d'Administration sur las situation des affaires de la Societe. 2.-Rapport de Messieurs les Censeurs. 3.-approbation des comptes et fixation du divedende. 4.-Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'e- xercice 1906 1907 et fixation de leur in- demnite annuelle. 5.-Renuvellement par tiers du Conseil d'Ad- ministration. 6.-Proposition diverses. Nota: Conformement a l'art. 37 des Status, tout porteur de 5 actions a droit d'assister a l'assemblee generale ordinaire. Les actions doivenetre deposees au Siege de la Societe, quinze jours au moins avant l'assemblee generale, c'est-a-dire, au plus tard le 15 Juin 1906 (Art. 28 des Statuts). Le President du Conseil d'Administration M. Sinadino Alexandrie, le 28 Mai 1906. 28007-3-1

div.head: Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat Egyptien

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et des telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneurde porter a la connaissance du public qu'a partir du 25 mai courant, l'horaire d'ouverture du Bureau tele- raphique de Guezireh, Caire, sera de 8 h. a.m. a 5 h. p.m. sans interruption. Le Caire, le 25 Maid 1906. 28000-2-1

Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;

Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
